items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] C.H.A.M.P. visits BOSLab (01-09-26). Field notes.
items.subject: C.H.A.M.P. visits BOSLab (01-09-26). Field notes.
items.htmlBody:
ï»¿Hello mushroom lovers,

We had a marvelous tour of BOSLab, the countryâ€™s first community biolab. C.H.A.M.P. members learned about opportunities for using equipment such as PCR thermal cyclers, fluorescence plate readers, incubators, and autoclaves. We discussed the possibilities for DNA barcoding/IT tagging, advanced microscopy, and a range of other art and bio-engineering projects.

We also exploredÂ creatingÂ C.H.A.M.P.Â /Â BOSLabÂ co-branded workshops, including sessions on cultivating mushrooms, hosting a crash course on microscopy and staining, and presenting talks and film screenings.

Lastly, we touched on outdoor programming such as using â€œLil Labâ€â€”a laboratory on wheels for conducting science au plein air!

If any of this excites you, send your thoughts to the C.H.A.M.P. suggestion box!

https://comm-hub-myco.github.io/champ-site/

Dr. Wendy Pouliot, neurobiologist and BOSLab President, with the 1940s windshield-wiper display cabinet she converted into â€œLil Lab,â€ a mobile research station outfitted with a trinocular stereo microscope. Underwritten by grants from the Massachusetts Cultural Council.

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] Call for ideas: C.H.A.M.P. - Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion
items.subject: Call for ideas: C.H.A.M.P. - Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion
items.htmlBody:
ï»¿Hello sub-group of Mushroom lovers,

I know all of you - to varying degrees - Â from our fledging and inchoate fungi affinity group, C.H.A.M.P.

Larry Millman, included here, and I meet regularly to discuss possible fungi-related projects, and I wanted to reach out to a wider group to cast seeds for more ideas.

This email grows out of the email below which I just received yesterday from the New England Botanic Garden. As youâ€™ll see, they are receptive to host / promote / and collaborate on mycology-themed content we develop.

Iâ€™m not fond of group e-mails, but Iâ€™m taking a chance this one will fertilize discussion between us and beyond.

Iâ€™d like to be the point person with the Botanic Garden at this early stage, so please share your thoughts with me directly.

Looking forward to see what Â incubates. My hope is that we can germinate viableÂ content rooted in your respective fields!

Jon Applefield
(917) 957-5152

Ps: To be reductive parenthetically, â€œweâ€ on this email thread are roughly: me (an art historian); Larry (ethnographer, writer, mycologist); Cody, Jula, and David (bio scientists - [sorry for lack of specifics]); Char (writer, myco-beverage entrepreneur, end-of-life doula); Amanda (Worcester-based mycologist- cultivator, entrepreneur); KieuLy and Sean (Worcester-based enthusiast and filmmakers).Â 

Begin forwarded message:

From: Alyson Prokop <aprokop@nebg.org>
Date: January 8, 2026 at 5:45:30â€¯PM EST
To: Jonathan Applefield <jonathan_applefield@hotmail.com>
Subject: RE: C.H.A.M.P. - Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion

ï»¿

Hi Jon,

Â 

Thank you so much for reaching outâ€”and for sharing the April 29 mushroom pigment program with your community. Iâ€™m delighted to hear it resonated, and I appreciate you including it on your calendar.

Â 

All three ideas youâ€™ve outlined absolutely resonate with me. Iâ€™m particularly interested in exploring May and June as potential windows for collaboration, though Iâ€™m very open to other times of year as well, depending on the format and scope.

Â 

The documentary screening and contextual talk sound especially compelling, and a guided mycology forayâ€”if structured to align with our site guidelinesâ€”could be a wonderful public-facing offering â€“ June would be perfect as we have a monthly speaker series, and I have yet to find a speaker for this month!

Â 

Iâ€™d be happy to set up a time to talk through possibilities, goals, and logistics, and to explore what a collaborative partnership (rather than a simple venue rental) could look like.

Â 

Let me know what your availability looks like in the coming weeks, and we can take it from there.

Â 

With thanks,

Aly

Â 

Alyson Prokop

Manager of Adult Education

she/her

Â 

New England Botanic Garden at Tower Hill

508.869.6111 x149
nebg.org

Â 

Â 

From: Jonathan Applefield <jonathan_applefield@hotmail.com>
Sent: December 15, 2025 2:11 PM
To: Alyson Prokop <aprokop@nebg.org>
Subject: C.H.A.M.P. - Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion

Â 

CAUTION: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.

Â 

Hello Allison,

Â 

I just got off the phone with Liz the register there. I am Jon Applefield - one of the organizers of a new group of mushroom enthusiast in the Boston area. Our group is C.H.A.M.P. (Community Hub for Actualizing Mycological Passion). Many of us are involved in the Boston Mycology Club, but this fall we started this group to foster citizen science and greater public outreach (rather than serving a niche of specialists).

Â 

Iâ€™m writing for a few purposes. First, I just wanted to let you know we listed your event on April 29 regarding dying with mushroom pigments on our websiteâ€™s calendar. Looks like a wonderful program.

Â 

https://comm-hub-myco.github.io/champ-site/calendar/

Â 

Second, weâ€™re in the planning phases of screening a fascinating ethnographic documentary on the mushroom culture of a group of Arctic peoples. One of our members, Lawrence Millman, is an expert on the Far North, having traveled dozens of times to Siberia, the Canadian Arctic, Greenland, and Norway. He is going to set the film into context, but Iâ€™m the logistics person.Â Â In this regard, I was exploring the idea of NEBG as a venue (not so much as a rental site, but a collaborative partner).

Â 

Finally, after speaking with Liz, I was curious if - with both parties consent - I might facilitate a mycology foray at your site guided by Mr. Millman. This would be open to the public and follow whatever guidelines you see fit.

Â 

Let me know if any of this resonates with you. Our timelines are not that rigid, but Iâ€™m of the opinion that itâ€™s always best to get things on the calendar when the inspiration is highest!

Â 

All the best,

Jon

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] Friday Field Trip (1/9); virtual event tonight
items.subject: Friday Field Trip (1/9); virtual event tonight
items.htmlBody:
Hello Mushroom Lover!

Iâ€™m excited to invite you to an in-person, on-site visit to BOSLabs (https://www.boslab.org/projects), a nonprofit community laboratory that makes cutting-edge biology hands-on and accessible to curious people outside traditional academia. If youâ€™re interested in fungi, this is a rare chance to see how tools like DNA sequencing, yeast engineering, imaging, and biochemistry can be used to identify, grow, study, and even design biological systemsâ€”sometimes in delightfully unexpected ways (theyâ€™ve even experimented with synthesizing truffle flavor in a lab). BOSLabs supports open, lay science: teaching, experimentation, and creative exploration across biology, chemistry, genetics, and bioengineering.


The on-site visit will take place on Friday, January 9, between noon and 7 pm (time to be determined). There will also be a virtual online open house happening tonight at 7 PM. RSVP here for virtual open house:


https://meetu.ps/e/PzDLC/B3jBy/i


If youâ€™re interested in the in-person visit, please email me with the times youâ€™d be available this Friday between noon and 7 pm, and Iâ€™ll confirm the time that works for the greatest number of people.


Thx,

Jon Applefield

items.subject: Ari - Project Idea
items.htmlBody:
Happy New Year to all ğŸ¥‚ğŸ¾ğŸ„
Here is a description of a possible project that CHAMP can take on. 
This is just an outline. It does not include technicalities. I can provide the technical methodology if a consensus is reached. 
The project entails placing a network of synchronized (programmable) LED lights under the surface of water. For example, â€œDuckpondâ€, at Boston Public Garden, this is where the Swan boats are. In the winter the pond is un-utilized. Procedurally, the LED-network will be installed in the pond before it freezes. When the pond does eventually freeze over, it will create the proper conditions to deliver an immersive, colorful light show, with images that appear emanating through the ice. The subject matter can widely vary, and include fungi with associated culturally-themed characters. This can also be set to sound affects. Funding for the project can be through the Mass Cultural Council. Or, directly from the city of Boston Art Commission.

                         Ari 

                Ari Stamatiou 
         Plimira@comcast.net
                617-962-8550

items.subjectRaw: [CHAMP: News] C.H.A.M.P.â€™s Weekend Update; Forecasting Next Events
items.subject: C.H.A.M.P.â€™s Weekend Update; Forecasting Next Events
items.htmlBody:
Report from C.H.A.M.P.â€™s 1st Foray, Lincoln, MA 12.7.25Â 

Larry started off saying something about the importance of noticing what we donâ€™t see, but the presence of negative data couldnâ€™t hold a candle to what materialized 10 minutes later: Bulgaria inquinans, commonly called Black Bulgar or Bachelorâ€™s Buttons â€“ bulbous protrusions like gobs of tar emerging from huge sawn logs â€“ oak, I believe. Matte black, like Finnish licorice, with cup-like depressions. I mistakenly thought the name had something to do with the former Soviet country, Bulgaria, but etymology filled the binomial with color and motion: â€œinflated,â€ â€œblister-like;â€ â€œdirtying,â€ â€œpolluting,â€ â€œblackening,â€ â€œstaining,â€ â€œmaking unclean.â€ So be it -Â  the dirty, bulging fungi left me feeling renewed. Larryâ€™s words and our presence as a group in the woods â€“ Jula, his Dad, Martin, and son Micha; Dan, Liam, Sean, KieuLy, Larry, and myself â€“ amplified a simple message: even on a chilly, steel-grey New England morning, the forest floor holds a cache of little treasures â€“ like Hanukkah gelt or Christmas cookies â€“ cups, crusts, and jellies, resplendent in a quiet but full-throated way, edging out the inelegant rumble of the MBTA commuter rail trundling by. Arboreal chamber music enjoyed from front-row seats, reminding me of John Cage, amateur mycologist and vanguard creator of aleatory music: â€œThere is no such thing as an empty space or an empty time. There is always something to see, something to hear. In fact, try as we may to make a silence, we cannot.â€

A quick rundown of notable species seen: a cascade of lumpy polypores â€“ Trametes gibbosa; oak-log sections tinted with green wood-staining fungus â€“ Chlorociboria sp.; tiny matchstick fungi â€“ Phaeocalicium polyporaeum â€“ lifting off from the margins of purple-tooth polypores â€“ Trichaptum abietinum; and, as if bidding us farewell like tiny munchkins from Oz, a â€œhairy fairyâ€ â€“ Lachnum virgineum; and a troupe of Mycena sp.

On the Horizon

Stay tuned for our next events. Plans are underfoot for a movie night pegged to an ethnographic film.
